EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

NORTH COUNTY REGIONAL WATER TREATMENT PLANT

RMP SUBMITTAL JANUARY 2012

Accidental Release and prevention and emergency response policy:

It is the policy of the Collier County Water Department to operate safe reliable water treatment facilities, reducing to the greatest extent possible hazards associated with the treatment process and the chemicals required as part of that process.  It is also the policy of the Collier County Water Department to work with surrounding community and local emergency response agencies, and promote a spirit of cooperation and teamwork to provide an effective contingency plan in the event that a process incident occurs at the North County Regional Water Treatment Plant (NCRWTP).    The first responder to any incident at the NCRWTP is the Golden Gate Fire Department (GGFD).  The GGFD works in close relation with the operations team at the NCRWTP, including training on site annually and sitting in on the annual review of the Risk Management Plan (RMP).  

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

The primary activity at the NCRWTP is a municipal water treatment plant.  Chlorine is the only 40 CFR 68 regulated substance at plant.  Chlorine is used primarily as a disinfectant.  The maximum amount of chlorine on site at this facility is 24 tons.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

Collier County is in compliance with 40 CFR 68. The County has conducted a comprehensive review of the chlorine system, as well as, administrative, technical, operating, and maintenance procedures.  In addition, all program elements have been reviewed by the County's internal safety auditors (Risk Management Department) and found to be in compliance.



The County has both passive mitigation, an enclosed building and active mitigation, an emergency scrubber, to minimize the consequences of an accidental release.  The Risk Management Program addresses actions to minimize the likeliho

od of an accidental release and minimize the impact if one was to occur.



Five Year Accident History:

There was one accident within the last five years that occurred on March 3, 2011.  The issue was the result of defective equipment provided by Collier County's at that time chlorine vendor.  The incident resulted in 1 pound of chlorine released within the chlorine room.  Internal on-site trained staff responded to the incident and was able to secure the cylinder.  The vendor removed the cylinder from the site within 48 hours.  After this incident the vendor was terminated.



Emergency Response Program:

The NCRWTP has an emergency response program that is coordinated with the Collier County Comprehensive Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that has been prepared in accordance with all local, state, and federal regulations.  The ERP for the NCRWTP specifically is attached to the RMP document as Attachment A to Chapter 9.  The ERP is reviewed annually by the Water Department management team.  Collier County conducts regular exercises on various components of the ERP, which the Water Department actively participates in. 





Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

As part of the Process Hazard Analysis that have been conducted every three years various actionable items have been identified.  The following is the update on the items that were pending since the last five year update to the RMP:



The current location of the header vacuum gauge and valves is a trip hazard. The header should be moved to a safer location to avoid potential falls, which could result in leakage at a valve.  

Outcome:  The Chlorine Room was reviewed by Camp, Dresser, and McKee Engineering firm and it was found that there was no alternative locations for the current equipment.  The area has been painted with bright paint and lighting is on at all times to alleviate the potential for trips or fall incidents.  Additionally, all NCRWTP are reminded annually of the importance of maintaining this area

clean and free of debris to also lessen the potential for trips and falls.



Provide local emergency responders with the revised RMP.

Outcome:  As noted above, the Water Department has developed a close working relationship with the various Fire Department's within the Collier County Water District.  The first responder to the NCRWTP is the Golden Gate Fire Department and the primary haz-mat responder is the North Naples Fire Department.  Both Department's have been provided copies of the Department's Risk Management Plans.



Write chlorine vendor to request all documentation of safety training that relates to off load and loading cylinders.

Outcome:  The Plant Manager annually updates the information maintained on file at the NCRWTP to document that all drivers sent to the Plant have been appropriately trained.



Provide updated awareness training to permit team regarding blasting restrictions in the area surrounding the Plant.  

Outcome:  The Collier County Growth Management Division is responsible for issuance of blasting permits for all of Collier County.  On the County's GIS the two regional water treatment plants, including the NCRWTP is clearly identified.  



Develop Job Safety Analysis (JSA) in addition to existing standard operating procedure for offloading and loading cylinders be sure it addresses chalking of cylinders, ergonomics (body mechanics), and crane inspection/operation.

Outcome:  JSA has been developed and is part of the NCRWTP RMP base document.



Install additional Wind Sox so one can be seen while standing at all areas from the ground on plant property.

Outcome:  The wind sock has been installed and a work order created in the NCRWTP's maintenance management software to replace twice per year.



Conduct 8HRs of HAZMAT Scenario training for all hazardous materials potential releases including chlorine and terrorist acts and community notification.  Work with local emergency responders to establish a notification protocol outcome to

be done by August 2007.

Outcome:  As noted above, regular annual exercises are conducted with the surrounding Fire Departments.



Review the ability to install a second egress route from the chlorine room. 

Outcome:  Camp, Dresser, and McKee Engineering firm was hired to address this item.  Due to the location of other NCRWTP processes, only one egress can be safely maintained.
